q: What are the symptoms of diverticular disease?
a: The symptoms of diverticular disease include pain in the lower left side of your abdomen, tummy pain that worsens after eating and improves after defecation, constipation, diarrhea, blood in stool, and bloating.

q: What urgent actions should you take if you have symptoms of diverticular disease?
a: If you have blood or slime in your stool, worsening or persistent tummy pain, high temperature, vomiting or inability to keep fluids down, or diarrhea for more than 7 days, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111.

q: What tests are conducted to diagnose diverticular disease?
a: To diagnose diverticular disease, a GP may ask questions, perform a blood test, and may require a stool sample. Further tests may include colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or a CT scan.

q: How is diverticular disease treated?
a: Treatment for diverticular disease includes painkillers like paracetamol, bulk-forming laxatives, and antispasmodic medicines to relieve stomach cramps.

q: What can you do to manage diverticular disease?
a: To manage diverticular disease, you can eat a healthy, balanced diet including whole grains, fruits, and vegetables, gradually increase fiber intake, stop smoking, and maintain a healthy weight. Avoid taking NSAIDs or opioid painkillers.

q: What are the complications of diverticulitis?
a: Complications of diverticulitis can include abscess formation, bowel blockage, fistula formation, and bowel perforation leading to peritonitis. These may require treatment with antibiotics or surgery.

q: When should immediate action be taken for diverticulitis?
a: Immediate action, such as calling 999 or going to A&E, is necessary if there is severe tummy pain accompanied by vomiting, swollen tummy, inability to pass stool or gas, heavy rectal bleeding, confusion, pale or blotchy skin, high or low temperature, or rapid breathing, as these could be signs of sepsis.

q: What are the symptoms of diverticulitis?
a: The symptoms of diverticulitis can include severe and constant tummy pain, high temperature, and rectal bleeding or passing mucus from the rectum.

q: What additional symptoms may indicate diverticulitis?
a: In addition to the common symptoms of diverticular disease, if your intestine becomes infected or inflamed, you may experience severe tummy pain, high temperature, and bleeding or passing slime from your bottom.

q: What are the tests used to diagnose diverticular disease and diverticulitis?
a: A GP may use a combination of questions, blood tests, stool samples, colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, and CT scan to diagnose diverticular disease and diverticulitis.

q: What are the symptoms of diverticular disease and diverticulitis?
a: The symptoms of diverticular disease include pain in the lower left or right side of the abdomen, pain that worsens after eating and improves after defecation or flatulence, constipation, diarrhea, blood in the stool, and bloating. Diverticulitis may also cause severe tummy pain, high temperature, and bleeding or passing mucus from the rectum.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for diverticular disease and diverticulitis?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111 if there is blood or mucus in your stool, your tummy pain is worsening or persistent, you have a high temperature, cannot keep fluids down, or have diarrhea for more than 7 days or vomiting for more than 2 days.

q: What tests might be done to diagnose diverticular disease and diverticulitis?
a: To diagnose diverticular disease and diverticulitis, the GP may ask questions about your symptoms. Further tests may include blood tests and stool samples to rule out other conditions. You might also need a colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or CT scan to confirm the diagnosis.

q: How can diverticular disease be treated?
a: Treatment for diverticular disease focuses on managing symptoms. This may include taking painkillers like paracetamol, using bulk-forming laxatives for constipation and diarrhea, and using antispasmodic medicines for stomach cramps.

q: How can diverticulitis be treated?
a: Diverticulitis is treated with antibiotics if it's caused by an infection. Painkillers like paracetamol may also be prescribed to help manage pain.

q: What can I do to help with diverticular disease and diverticulitis?
a: To help manage diverticular disease and diverticulitis, you can eat a healthy, balanced diet including whole grains, fruits, and vegetables. It's also important to slowly increase fiber intake, stop smoking if you smoke, and maintain a healthy weight. Avoid taking NSAIDs or opioid painkillers as they can worsen stomach problems and increase the risk of bowel perforation.

q: What are the complications of diverticulitis?
a: Complications of diverticulitis include abscess formation, bowel blockage, bowel opening to another organ (fistula), and bowel perforation leading to peritonitis. These complications may require treatment with antibiotics or surgery, including abscess drainage or removal of the affected bowel segment. In some cases, a colostomy may be necessary.

q: When should I seek immediate medical attention for diverticulitis?
a: If you or someone you care for experiences severe tummy pain accompanied by vomiting, swollen abdomen, inability to defecate or pass gas, heavy rectal bleeding, confusion, pale or blotchy skin, very high or low temperature, or rapid breathing, it may indicate a medical emergency such as sepsis. Call 999 or go to A&E immediately.

q: What are the symptoms of diverticular disease?
a: The symptoms of diverticular disease include pain in the lower left side of your tummy, tummy pain that gets worse after eating and gets better after pooping or farting, constipation, diarrhea, blood in your poop, and bloating.

q: What are the symptoms of diverticulitis?
a: The symptoms of diverticulitis include severe, constant tummy pain, high temperature, bleeding or passing slime (mucus) from your bottom.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for diverticular disease or diverticulitis?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if there is blood or slime in your poop, you have worsening or persistent tummy pain, you have a high temperature, or you have diarrhea for more than 7 days or vomiting for more than 2 days.

q: What tests may be done to diagnose diverticular disease or diverticulitis?
a: The GP may ask you questions and may recommend a blood test or a poo sample to help diagnose the condition. Further tests may include a colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy, or a CT scan.

q: How can diverticular disease be treated?
a: Treatments for diverticular disease include painkillers, bulk-forming laxatives, and medicines to help with stomach cramps.

q: What should I do to manage diverticular disease or diverticulitis?
a: To manage diverticular disease, you can eat a healthy, balanced diet including whole grains, fruits, and vegetables, slowly increase your fiber intake, drink plenty of water, stop smoking if you smoke, and maintain a healthy weight. Avoid taking NSAIDs or opioid painkillers.

q: What are the complications of diverticulitis?
a: Complications of diverticulitis can include abscess, bowel blockage, bowel opening to another organ (fistula), and bowel perforation. These complications may require treatment with antibiotics or surgery.

q: When should I seek immediate medical attention for diverticular disease or diverticulitis?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you have severe tummy pain and are vomiting, have a swollen tummy, or cannot poop or fart, if you are bleeding heavily from your bottom, or if you have signs of sepsis such as confusion, pale or blotchy skin, high or low temperature, or rapid breathing.
